analysis:
────────────────────────────────
**Summary**
• Cloudflare revoked a private key after discovering it was briefly accessible, leading to the mis-issuance of TLS certificates for the 1.1.1.1 resolver.
• The incident could have allowed attackers to impersonate the 1.1.1.1 resolver, potentially exposing user queries.
• The number of mis-issued certificates has grown, increasing the potential attack surface.
• Cloudflare has taken steps to mitigate the issue, including revoking the compromised key and the mis-issued certificates.

**Why it matters**
• Users of the 1.1.1.1 resolver should be aware of the potential risks and ensure their systems are updated to recognize the revoked certificates.
• Companies and developers relying on Cloudflare's services need to stay informed about security incidents and mitigation measures to protect their users and infrastructure.

**Risks**
• Attackers could exploit the mis-issued certificates to conduct man-in-the-middle attacks, potentially intercepting or manipulating user queries.

**Opportunities**
• This incident highlights the importance of robust key management practices and incident response procedures for all organizations involved in issuing and managing TLS certificates.

**Market view**
Market — Heightened awareness of certificate management and security practices.

**Sources**
https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2025/09/the-number-of-mis-issued-1-1-1-1-certificates-grows-heres-the-latest/

────────────────────────────────
